newsitem.title: EGYPT: Egypt's Suez Canal revenues fall in 1996.
newsitem.headline: Egypt's Suez Canal revenues fall in 1996.

text.p: Suez Canal revenues fell to $1.881 billion in 1996 from $1.959 billion in 1995, the Suez Canal Authority (SCA) statistics department said on Thursday.
The deparment said that 14,731 ships used the canal in 1996 but did not give comparative figures.
Revenues from the Suez Canal are one of the four major foreign currency earners in Egypt.

The canal, facing competition from the SUMED pipeline which pumps crude oil from the Red Sea to the Mediterranean and from the Cape route around African's southern tip, is fighting hard to win back traffic.
In November the SCA announced a package of bargains it hopes will lure traffic away from alternative routes and back to the strategic waterway.
The canal also decided to leave unchanged in 1997 transit dues for all types of ships travelling through the canal. It is the third year in a row that the SCA has not changed the fees.
The SCA is also holding talks with Jordan to increase traffic between the canal and the Red Sea port of Aqaba.
